Title: Truth and Semantics

This project, "Truth and Semantics," proposes a unified perspective on natural language semantics, conceived of as truth-conditional semantics, and its relationship to the research on semantic paradoxes in the form of theories of self-applicable truth. The project tackles two interconnected challenges: "Truth in Semantics" and "Truth and the Foundations of Semantics." The first challenge aims to develop semantic accounts for rich fragments of natural language, focusing on the notion of truth, modal expressions, propositional attitudes, and natural language conditionals. The second challenge adopts a metasemantic perspective to investigate the role of the notion of truth in the foundations of natural language semantics. By addressing these challenges, the project seeks to provide the first systematic study of truth and natural language semantics from a combined perspective. The expected outcome is a comprehensive understanding of the interplay between truth and natural language semantics, which will have significant implications for the development of formal semantic theories and the foundations of linguistic meaning. The project's innovative approach will bridge the gap between philosophical and linguistic research, fostering a deeper understanding of the complex relationships between truth, language, and meaning.
